text:
Hi <@U088WG9UYK1> / <@U0821PFKM0V>, Just checking back in on the status of mainnet onboarding and whitelisting for Blueprint—we’re still standing by for access and the onboarding secret when slots become available.

In the meantime, we’ve successfully tested DevNet operations, including validator upgrades and full backup recovery (we’ve scripted and validated the upgrade flow based on Sync’s official guidance). We’re ready to move when given the green light. Do you have any updated outlook from the committee on when the cap might lift? And would it be helpful for us to continue checking in every few days, or is there a better cadence you’d recommend?

elements.text:

Both our node and the SV <https://sv.sv-1.dev.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com> are on splice 0.4.3. It seems to be stuck waiting for a version check via scan. text:
Hey Wayne, what would you state is the major definition / difference between SV managed global synchronizers vs these private decentralized synchronizers. Would the following be accurate understandings
• Private decentralized synchronizers are non regulated, high throughput synchronizers that is good for interaction between a close set of parties and do not require the use of canton coins to regulate the amount of traffic that the members can send to it
• Global synchronizers would be regulated controlled  synchronizers that use canton coin to regulate traffic and act as a bridge between the these private synchronizers to support cross domain interactions.

elements.text: Hey Wayne, what would you state is the major definition / difference between SV managed global synchronizers vs these private decentralized synchronizers. Would the following be accurate understandings

Private decentralized synchronizers are non regulated, high throughput synchronizers that is good for interaction between a close set of parties and do not require the use of canton coins to regulate the amount of traffic that the members can send to it

Global synchronizers would be regulated controlled  synchronizers that use canton coin to regulate traffic and act as a bridge between the these private synchronizers to support cross domain interactions.

text: In the documentation, I see several mentions of things like "You can open your browser at <https://cns.validator.YOUR_HOSTNAME> and login" but no mention of actually creating DNS records for that. Is the admin expected to be configuring DNS aliases for `{cns,wallet,etc}.<http://validator.MY|validator.MY>_HOSTNAME`  pointing to the same place?

text:
When working on a custom KMS driver, I supposed we will need to bundle our JAR file, or extend the docker images to add our JAR file in somewhere in classpath?

Or is there a mechanism that the canton validator/participant docker image support to load or mount these files into a pre-defined well-known directory?
